Answer: If you’re referring to carbon footprint then yes. Many cryptocurrencies today have very limited to zero carbon emissions. However, unlike bitcoin these cryptos are proof of stake as opposed to proof of work.

Or even better, if a miner turns someone into an evangelist for a coin, a “hodler”: then the difficulty of mining that cryptocurrency goes up.However, there is now another person holding that coin (at least for a short period of time, if they’Your question highlights one of the most impressive elements of Blockchain technology.Incentives.If a miner gets another miner to join the network and mine. Or even better, if a miner turns someone into an evangelist for a coin, a “hodler”: then the difficulty of mining that cryptocurrency goes up.However, there is now another person holding that coin (at least for a short period of time, if they’re cashing out all their profits).If they decide to hold the coin and hope the price goes up (like the guy who convinced them to start mining probably is) then they’re holding the coin, and therefore not increasing the total supply by putting their coins into the market.If they decide to sell, they’re going to be selling at a pretty modest rate and it...

It can also transact in a few seconds, not the 10–60 minutes required by BTC.There’s a load of videos on YouTube explaining how HBAR achieves this, and to be honest, I’m surprised it isn’t far bigger than it is.

Answer: Musk announced his new position in a major U-turn on Wednesday, prompting speculation among some experts about whether he had a plan to wean the crypto industry off the fossil fuels that power "mining," the energy-intensive process that creates coins.Tesla could itself take an active role in helping make bitcoin greener by investing in new projects aimed at boosting the use of renewable energy in mining, according to more than a dozen cryptocurrency specialists interviewed by Reuters."Musk and Tesla certainly have the resources to support existing efforts to fully move bitcoin to renewable eneMusk announced his new position in a major U-turn on Wednesday, prompting speculation among some experts about whether he had a plan to wean the crypto industry off the fossil fuels that power "mining," the energy-intensive process that creates coins.Tesla could itself take an active role in helping make bitcoin greener by investing in new projects aimed at boosting the use of renewable energy in mining, according to more than a dozen cryptocurrency specialists interviewed by Reuters."Musk and Tesla certainly have the resources to support existing efforts to fully move bitcoin to renewable energy," said Diana Biggs, CEO of crypto startup Valour.But such ventures could take years to get off the ground.
